question: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 µm) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism.
options:
a)cystoisospora
b)cyclospora
c)cryptosporidium
d)Microspora
solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as cystoisospora.
points in favor:
• HIV patient with diarrhea
• oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with kinyoun staining.
comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

property	cryptosporidium	cyclospora	cystoisospora
sporulated oocyst	4-6 µm, round,  contains f our sporozoites	8-12 µm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having t wo sporozoites	23-36 µm, oval, contain t  wo sporocysts, each havin g four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection	uniformly acid-fast	Variable acid-fast	uniformly acid-fast
sporulation of the ooc yst	occurs inside the host cell	occurs in soil	occurs in soil


property	cryptosporidium	cyclospora	cystoisospora
Diagnostic form	sporulated cyst	unsporulated cyst	unsporulated oocyst


Modified acid-fast staining (like kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of cyclospora cayetanensis.


Modified acid-fast staining (like kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of cryptosporidium species.  In immunocompromised patients, the infection causes severe diarrhea similar to cholera and require hospitalization.
The diagnosis is made with stool microscopy. The cyst wall and sporoblasts are dyed red with the ziehl–Neelsen (warm) or kinyoun (cold) staining methods. Both methods have good specificity     and therefore are useful as confirmatory tests.
The treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

question: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying ____________.
options:
a)staphylococcus aureus
b)streptococcus pyogenes
c)clostridium botulinum
d)Bacillus
solution:
The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.
Among the options given, streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.
streptococci belonging to group A are identified (presumptively) by inhibition of growth by bacitracin.

question: what is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum?
options:
a)1-5 days
b)7-1o days
c)1o-3o days
d)3o-6o days
solution:
The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 1o-3o days.
chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The   most common presentation is the inguinal syndrome, which is characterized by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

question: which is the agent used to treat the infection caused by the cestode egg in the image?
options:
a)praziquantel
b)Ivermectin
c)Albendazole
d)Diethylcarbamazine
solution:
The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by
praziquantel (5–1o mg/kg once).
The egg is oval, colorless, non-bile stained, and has a single shell with two distinct membranes.
Inner membrane has two small knobs or poles from which 4 to 8 polar filaments arise and spread out between the two membranes. It is embryonated and the oncosphere has six hooks (three pairs of hooklets).
Life cycle of Hymenolepis nana:


Hymenolepiasis is the most common of all the cestode infections and is usually asymptomatic.

question: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except ______.
options:
a)kaposi sarcoma
b)castleman’s disease
c)Adult T-cell leukemia
d)primary effusion lymphoma
solution:
Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).
Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (kSHV), is lymphotropic virus and is closely related to Ebstein–Barr virus (EBV).
Diseases caused by HHV:
• kaposi sarcomas
• Vascular tumors of mixed cellular composition
• Body cavity-based lymphomas occurring in AIDS patients (primary effusion lymphoma)
• Multicentric castleman disease

question: Identify the condenser in the following image.
options:
a)Above the stage
b)Below the stage
c)Near the eyepiece
d)Above the objective lenses
solution:
This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage.


The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens.
The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by
Hans and zacharias Janssen uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.

question: The following test is positive for identification of________
options:
a)candida albicans
b)candida glabrata
c)Candida parapsilosis
d)Candida tropicalis
solution:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.
Candida species, when cultured, grow as oval, budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. Unlike
other species of candida, Candida albicans can also produce true hyphae or germ tubes. This can be demonstrated after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 9o minutes. This is
known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well. Another distinguishing feature of C. albicans is that it produces large, spherical chlamydospores   on nutritionally deficient media.

question: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.
options:
a)Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
b)CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
c)Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
d)UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to foscarnet
solution:
Resistance to ganciclovir most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97
phosphotransferase gene.
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a beta-herpes virus. It is the most common congenital infection. In
adults, its disease is mostly subclinical (option C). An apparent CMV infection resembles
infectious mononucleosis (fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes and splenomegaly). It is the   most common infection in the donor organ seen 1-4 months after solid organ transplantation. In immunosuppressed hosts, it causes pneumonia and colitis.
Diagnosis is by PCR assays. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts (option B) and can thus be cultured in them, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the  host. The cultured fibroblasts show owl-eye inclusion bodies after 2-3 weeks.
UL54 (DNA polymerase) gene mutations can confer CMV resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir and foscarnet (option D).

question: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur?
options:
a)Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
b)Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)
c)Hepatitis B Virus (HBV)
d)Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)
solution:
Solvent detergent plasma is a form of blood plasma made from plasma collected from many
people which is then processed with solvents to try to get rid of viruses. HAV is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it s not affected by solvent/detergent (SD) plasma.
only the viruses with an envelope are susceptible to SD plasma destruction.
Hepatitis B, C, and HIV are enveloped.

question: plasma sterilization makes use of_____________.
options:
a)Hydrogen peroxide
b)Ethylene oxide
c)Gamma rays
d)UV rays
solution:
A variety of hydrogen peroxide gas  based processes that use plasma as part of the sterilization process are known as "plasma sterilization."
The mechanisms of antimicrobial action in these processes are primarily due to hydrogen
peroxide gas (or condensed gas) and not plasma, although the plasma generation phase of these processes is known to assist in the breakdown of residual peroxide in the chamber load.

question: Identify the organism below that causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
options:
a)ETEC
b)EIEC
c)EPEC
d)EAEC
solution:
Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).
E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.
EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.
Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:
•  Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
•  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.


The image below shows an electron microscopy image of E Coli.

question: which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication?
options:
a)Hepatitis virus
b)Influenza virus
c)HIV
d)Herpes virus
solution:
The given image shows generation of mRNA from negative sense RNA within the nucleus. This occurs during the replication of influenza virus.
orthomyxoviruses (influenza virus) contain segmented (8 segments) negative sense ssRNA that is replicated in the nucleus. stages of viral replication include the following:
• Attachment, penetration, uncoating: The virus attaches to cell-surface sialic acid via
hemagglutinin. It is then internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis. There is fusion of the
viral envelope and cell membrane, resulting in uncoating or release of nucleocapsid into the host cell cytoplasm.
• Transcription and translation:  mRNAs are produced from nucleocapsids via a virus-encoded polymerase. This process occurs in the nucleus. The mRNAs thus produced are translated into viral proteins in the cytoplasm.
• viral RNA replication: The viral genome is replicated by the same virus-encoded polymerase involved in transcription. The negative sense RNA is converted to its positive sense form. The positive sense copies serve as templates for replication of the viral genome.
• Maturation: The virus matures by budding from the surface of the cell.

question: which method of diagnosis is shown in the image?
options:
a)Darkfield microscopy
b)phase contrast microscopy
c)Fluorescent microscopy
d)Electron microscopy
solution:
The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.
The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies.
Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum.

question: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
options:
a)Ancylostoma duodenale
b)strongyloides stercoralis
c)Ascaris lumbricoides
d)Enterobius vermicularis
solution:
The image shows the life cycle of strongyloides stercoralis.
strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode known to cause human infection. It has both a free-living and a parasitic life cycle. Its natural host is man. The infective form to man is the
filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, the
larvae migrate to the small intestine. They molt twice and become adult female worms in the
small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the
rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). Thus, it is ovoviviparous. These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter
the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.
The rhabditiform larva can also be passed in the stool. It may directly metamorphose to the
infective filariform larva in the soil, or develop into adult worms. The free-living adult worms then pass eggs, which hatch and mature to form infective filariform larvae.
In Ancylostoma duodenale infestation, eggs containing segmented ova (not rhabditiform larvae)   are passed in the stool. The rhabditiform larva hatches 2 days after the eggs are passed in the soil.
Note: Based on the method of reproduction, nematodes are classified as follows:
• oviparous - They lay eggs:
• unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria
• segmented eggs:  Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus
• Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis
• viviparous - They produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi
• ovoviviparous – They lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., strongyloides stercoralis

question: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following?
options:
a)DNA
b)RNA
c)proteins
d)None
solution:
Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.
southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA and western blotting is used for the detection of protein.

question:
A cook prepares sandwiches for 1o people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on
investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
options:
a)salmonella typhi
b)vibrio cholera
c)Entamoeba histolytica
d)staphylococcus aureus
solution:
The cook is most likely to be carrier of staph. aureus.
The onset of food poisioning with in 4-6 hrs of food is mainly due to:
• staphylococcus aureus
• Bacillius cereus (has no carriers)

question: The following image depicts:
options:
a)production of monoclonal antibodies
b)cell lines for viral culture
c)vaccine synthesis
d)process of genetic engineering
solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.
The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:
• Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
• when the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen,   without adjuvant, intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
• Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span, with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of   unlimited growth.
• The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
• Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

question:
A patient has complains of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. what are the
constituents of Albert's stain?
options:
a)carbol fuschin and methylene blue
b)carbol fuschin and malachite green
c)Toluidine and malachite green
d)Toluidine and methylene blue
solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of diphtheria caused by corynebacterium diphtheria. This organism is stained using Albert's stain which contains toluidine blue 'o' and malachite
green. Both these dyes have an affinity for acidic cytoplasm as they are basic dyes.
Albert’s, Neisser’s, and ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules(volutin / Babes Ernst granules) of corynebacterium diphtheria.
corynebacterium diphtheria appears as green-coloured bacilli with purple-blue-coloured metachromatic granules in cuneiform arrangement.

question: which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain?
options:
a)Giardia
b)Entamoeba
c)campylobacter
d)staphylococcus aureus
solution:
stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.
Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:
• Acute intestinal amebiasis presents as dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. stools usually have blood and mucus.
• Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
• A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.
other options:
option a - Giardia is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence.
option c - Campylobacter presents with fever, pain and bloody or watery diarrhea. stool contains leucocytes and blood.
option d - staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

question:
A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to
_____
options:
a)virus
b)Bacteria
c)Fungi
d)Mycoplasma
solution:
Interferon-beta is secreted during infection due to viruses.
Interferons are classified as cytokines. Interferons are non-toxic, non-antigenic and
species-specific molecules. They are inactivated by proteases. They are stable at pH over 2-1o, except INF-? (labile at pH 2) and are non-dialysable and non-sedimentable.
There are three types of interferons - a , ß and ?. IFN-a or leukocyte interferon is produced by
leucocytes. It has antiviral activity, is immunoregulaotry and antiproliferative. IFN-ß or fibroblast interferon is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It has antiviral activity and is thus
increased in viral infections. It enhances MHC class 1 and NK cell activity. IFN-? or immune
interferon is produced by T-lymphocytes, NK cells . It activates macrophages, increases neutrophil function, enhances both MHC class 1 and class II expression and has anti-proliferative
(anti-tumour) functions.

question: which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells?
options:
a)Mature dendritic cells
b)Follicular dendritic cells
c)B lymphocytes
d)NK cells
solution:
Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells.
Naive CD4+ T cells are activated when they come in contact with two ligands - MHC class II and a costimulary membrane protein (eg: CD28). Both of these are present in antigen-presenting cells,    the most potent of which is the mature dendritic cell. other professional antigen-presenting cells   include macrophages and B lymphocytes (option C).
other options:

option B: Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.
option D: NK cells do not stimulate naive T cells.

question: which of the following is an immunologically privileged site?
options:
a)seminiferous tubule
b)Area postrema
c)optic nerve
d)Loop of Henle
solution:
The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.
Immunologically privileged sites can tolerate the introduction of antigens without eliciting an  immune response. This allows a higher likelihood of graft survival, even without perfect HLA   matching. As a result, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.
The unique immune tolerance in these regions is primarily due to the lack of effective lymphatic drainage, which prevents antigen presentation to the immune system, and the presence of
blood-tissue barriers that restrict immune cell infiltration. Low vascularity contributes to immune privilege by minimising antigen exposure and immune cell recruitment.
Examples of immune-privileged sites are the anterior chamber of the eye, cornea, testes, and brain.
Note: Although part of the brain, the blood-brain barrier is absent at the area postrema, therefore it is not an immune-privileged site.

question: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. which of the following is true?
options:
a)Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
b)It is an obligate extracellular parasite
c)It is transmitted from sheep
d)stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India.
solution:
The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in
macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.
visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a
protozoan parasite of genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the

bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sand flies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.
In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestation:
• Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
• cutaneous leishmaniasis,
• Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
• Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.
The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,
• The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
• The amastigote which multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.
It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.
Diagnosis:
• Rapid diagnostic test: rk39 Rapid diagnostic test and kala azar dipstick test strip.
• parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
• Aldehyde test of Napier: widely used for surveillance.
• serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELIsA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test
• Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually      positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.
Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 1omg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in
India.

question: which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults?
options:
a)Azithromycin
b)ciprofloxacin
c)ceftriaxone
d)Amikacin
solution:
Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever.
Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual
clinical cases.
